title: How to Cook Country Style Ribs

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 300 °F (149 °C) and prep the ribs.
steps.description: Let the oven heat up while you're getting the ribs ready. Line a rimmed baking sheet with foil or parchment paper and lay the ribs out in a single layer. Sprinkle salt and pepper on both sides. Use 2 trays if the ribs won't fit on one in a single layer. You can use bone-in or boneless ribs.

steps.headline: Cover the ribs with foil and bake them for 2 hours.
steps.description: Use foil to make a tight lid over the ribs. Let them cook for at least 2 hours. Don't take them out of the oven  during this time. You don't even really need to check on them. Basically, you're braising the ribs in their own juice at this point, as they will render fat and liquid as they cook.

steps.headline: Take the ribs out to pour off the grease.
steps.description: Carefully uncover the ribs, as the steam will be hot. Remove the ribs from the pan momentarily, and drain the grease into a can to throw away later. Set the ribs back on the baking tray. If the ribs don't seem tender when you uncover them, put them back in the oven under the cover for another 15-30 minutes. They should be starting to soften but not fully tender yet.

steps.headline: Brush the ribs with sauce.
steps.description: You can use any kind of sauce you want or even make your own. Place the ribs back on the pan before brushing the tops with sauce. Just use enough to coat the ribs thoroughly. Barbecue sauce works greats for this purpose! You can also try teriyaki sauce, hoisin sauce, or really any thick sauce that has some oil in it.

steps.headline: Turn the oven up to 350 °F (177 °C) and put the ribs back in.
steps.description: Leave the ribs uncovered, and let them cook for 15-30 minutes at this temperature. This process will start caramelizing the barbecue sauce.

steps.headline: Turn and baste the ribs every 15-30 minutes until they're tender.
steps.description: Pull the ribs out of the oven and turn them over. Brush barbecue sauce on the other side. Put them back in the oven to heat some more. Repeat the process until the ribs are tender and falling off the bone, which should take about 90 minutes.

steps.headline: Broil the ribs for 1-2 minutes at the end to caramelize the sauce.
steps.description: Once the ribs seem tender enough, add one more layer of barbecue sauce. Watch them closely while they're broiling, and take them out before they start burning.

steps.headline: Wash and chop the vegetables.
steps.description: Wash the vegetables under running water, scrubbing them lightly with a vegetable scrubber. Chop the carrot, onion, and celery stalk into small pieces. Mince the 4 garlic cloves finely. You can peel the carrot if you'd like, but it's not necessary if you scrub it well enough.

steps.headline: Heat 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of oil in a Dutch oven on the stove.
steps.description: Place the pot over medium-high heat. Let the oil heat up for a minute or two. While it's heating, take time to prep the ribs for browning.

steps.headline: Season the ribs with salt and pepper to prepare them for browning.
steps.description: Take the ribs out of the package. Pat the ribs dry with a paper towel so they'll brown properly. Salt and pepper both sides of the ribs.

steps.headline: Brown the ribs in the Dutch oven for 1-2 minutes on each side.
steps.description: Set them in the oil one at a time. The ribs will begin to brown on the side that's in the pan. Turn the ribs after a minute or two, so you brown all the sides of the ribs. Don't crowd the pan with ribs, as they won't brown. If you need to, brown the ribs one or two at a time. Set the ribs to the side for a moment.

steps.headline: Add 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of oil to the pan and cook the veggies.
steps.description: Turn the heat down on the pan to medium, and add the carrot, onion, and celery. Let them cook for 3-4 minutes, then scrape in the minced garlic. Let it cook for a minute or so.

steps.headline: Spoon in the tomato paste, apple cider vinegar, and bay leaves.
steps.description: Add the tomato paste first, and let it cook for a couple of minutes. Pour in the apple cider vinegar, and use it to help scrape off what's on the bottom of the pan. Drop the bay leaves into the pan. You can add a pinch of red pepper flakes at this point if you'd like a little heat.

steps.headline: Pour in the 2.5 cups (590 mL) of chicken stock and put the ribs back in.
steps.description: The chicken stock will not completely submerge the ribs. Let the stock come up to a simmer, and then cover the ribs to transfer them to the oven. Make sure the ribs are tightly covered.

steps.headline: Cook the ribs in a 350 °F (177 °C) oven for 1 1/2 hours.
steps.description: The ribs will slowly braise during this time. After an hour or so, take the lid off the ribs. The heat will reduce the sauce, as well as give the ribs some color. Serve the ribs with mashed potatoes or polenta.

steps.headline: Mix the dry rub together.
steps.description: Place the 2 tablespoons (25 g) of brown sugar, 2 teaspoons (5 g) of ancho chile, 2 teaspoons (5 g) of chipotle chile, 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground cumin, 1/2 teaspoon (1.4 g) of garlic powder, 1/2 teaspoon (1.4 g) of onion powder, and 2 tablespoons (36 g) of kosher salt in a small bowl. Stir the spices to combine. You can also use a marinade instead.

steps.headline: Apply the dry rub to the ribs.
steps.description: Use your hands to massage the dry rub into the ribs, making sure to get it all over the meat. If you want, you can use latex gloves for this process so you're not coating your hands with seasonings and meat juice.

steps.headline: Leave the ribs overnight in the fridge.
steps.description: Place the ribs in a zip-top bag, and put them in the refrigerator for 8 hours. If you're in a hurry, you can cook them after 4 hours instead of 8. Pull the ribs out of the fridge an hour before you want to cook them so they can come to room temperature.

steps.headline: Heat the grill up to medium high.
steps.description: Aim for 350 to 450 °F (177 to 232 °C) with your gas or charcoal grill. Let the grill heat up all the way before you cook the ribs.

steps.headline: Cook both flat sides of the ribs for about 6 minutes on each side.
steps.description: Start by placing the largest side face down. They should be crusty on that side before you turn them over. Let the other side cook about 6 minutes, too.

steps.headline: Grill the thin sides of the ribs.
steps.description: Turn the ribs up on one side, and cook them for another 5 minutes or so. Once that side is crusty, turn them over to the other thin side, and cook that side for 5 minutes. You may need to lean the ribs against each other to grill the thin sides.

steps.headline: Let the ribs rest for 5 minutes before serving.
steps.description: Remove the ribs from the grill and cover them with a tent of foil. Letting them rest 5 minutes will help keep the juice in the meat when you cut into it.

You can peel the carrot if you'd like, but it's not necessary if you scrub it well enough. Heat 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of oil in a Dutch oven on the stove. Place the pot over medium-high heat. Let the oil heat up for a minute or two. While it's heating, take time to prep the ribs for browning. Season the ribs with salt and pepper to prepare them for browning. Take the ribs out of the package. Pat the ribs dry with a paper towel so they'll brown properly. Salt and pepper both sides of the ribs. Brown the ribs in the Dutch oven for 1-2 minutes on each side. Set them in the oil one at a time. The ribs will begin to brown on the side that's in the pan. Turn the ribs after a minute or two, so you brown all the sides of the ribs. Don't crowd the pan with ribs, as they won't brown. If you need to, brown the ribs one or two at a time. Set the ribs to the side for a moment. Add 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of oil to the pan and cook the veggies. Turn the heat down on the pan to medium, and add the carrot, onion, and celery. Let them cook for 3-4 minutes, then scrape in the minced garlic. Let it cook for a minute or so. Spoon in the tomato paste, apple cider vinegar, and bay leaves. Add the tomato paste first, and let it cook for a couple of minutes. Pour in the apple cider vinegar, and use it to help scrape off what's on the bottom of the pan. Drop the bay leaves into the pan. You can add a pinch of red pepper flakes at this point if you'd like a little heat. Pour in the 2.5 cups (590 mL) of chicken stock and put the ribs back in. The chicken stock will not completely submerge the ribs. Let the stock come up to a simmer, and then cover the ribs to transfer them to the oven. Make sure the ribs are tightly covered. The heat will reduce the sauce, as well as give the ribs some color. Serve the ribs with mashed potatoes or polenta. Making Grilled Country Style Ribs Mix the dry rub together. Place the 2 tablespoons (25 g) of brown sugar, 2 teaspoons (5 g) of ancho chile, 2 teaspoons (5 g) of chipotle chile, 1/2 teaspoon (1 g) of ground cumin, 1/2 teaspoon (1.4 g) of garlic powder, 1/2 teaspoon (1.4 g) of onion powder, and 2 tablespoons (36 g) of kosher salt in a small bowl. Stir the spices to combine. You can also use a marinade instead. Apply the dry rub to the ribs. Use your hands to massage the dry rub into the ribs, making sure to get it all over the meat. If you want, you can use latex gloves for this process so you're not coating your hands with seasonings and meat juice. Leave the ribs overnight in the fridge. Place the ribs in a zip-top bag, and put them in the refrigerator for 8 hours. If you're in a hurry, you can cook them after 4 hours instead of 8. Pull the ribs out of the fridge an hour before you want to cook them so they can come to room temperature. Heat the grill up to medium high. Aim for 350 to 450 °F (177 to 232 °C) with your gas or charcoal grill. Let the grill heat up all the way before you cook the ribs. Cook both flat sides of the ribs for about 6 minutes on each side. Start by placing the largest side face down. They should be crusty on that side before you turn them over. Let the other side cook about 6 minutes, too. Grill the thin sides of the ribs. Turn the ribs up on one side, and cook them for another 5 minutes or so. Once that side is crusty, turn them over to the other thin side, and cook that side for 5 minutes. You may need to lean the ribs against each other to grill the thin sides. Let the ribs rest for 5 minutes before serving. Remove the ribs from the grill and cover them with a tent of foil. Letting them rest 5 minutes will help keep the juice in the meat when you cut into it.
